transcript:
Patient: Last session, you asked me to continue practicing thought records, share a small piece of my experience with my sibling, and track my progress with the pain management plan. I've been trying to do the thought records every day, but it's been challenging to stay consistent. I did share a little bit with my sibling about my struggles, and their response was more supportive than I expected.

Therapist: It's great that you've been working on the thought records, even if it's been challenging to stay consistent. Building new habits takes time and practice. I'm also glad to hear that sharing with your sibling went better than you anticipated. How did it feel to open up to them a bit?

Patient: It was scary at first, but afterwards, I felt a sense of relief. Like a weight had been lifted off my shoulders. I guess I've been so used to keeping everything to myself that I forgot how good it feels to have someone listen and understand.

Therapist: That's a powerful insight, Jamie. Opening up to others can be difficult, especially when we're used to keeping things to ourselves. But as you experienced, it can also provide a sense of relief and connection. I'm curious, what did you share with your sibling, and how did they respond?

Patient: I told them about how my chronic pain has been affecting my mood and motivation. I didn't go into too much detail, but I wanted them to know that it's been a struggle. They listened and told me that they're always here for me if I need to talk. They even offered to come with me to my next doctor's appointment if I wanted support.

Therapist: It sounds like your sibling really cares about you and wants to be there for you. How did their response make you feel?

Patient: I felt grateful and loved. It made me realize that I don't have to go through this alone, even though I often feel like I should be able to handle everything myself.

Therapist: That's a significant realization, Jamie. Recognizing that you don't have to go through this alone and that it's okay to lean on others for support is an important step in your recovery. It's common for people to feel like they should be able to handle everything on their own, but the truth is, we all need support at times.

Let's take a look at the thought records you've been working on. Can you share an example of a thought record you completed this week?

Patient: Sure. One day, I was feeling really down about my writing. My automatic thought was "I'll never be a successful writer because of my chronic pain." I rated my emotions as sadness (8/10) and hopelessness (7/10). When I looked at the evidence for and against this thought, I realized that there are many successful writers who have chronic pain or other health issues. And even though my pain makes writing more challenging, it doesn't mean I can't still pursue my passion. I reframed the thought to "My chronic pain may make writing more difficult, but it doesn't define my worth or potential as a writer." Afterward, my sadness decreased to a 5/10, and my hopelessness went down to a 4/10.

Therapist: That's a fantastic example of using a thought record to challenge a negative automatic thought. You did a great job of examining the evidence for and against the thought and coming up with a more balanced alternative. It's also significant that you noticed a decrease in the intensity of your emotions after reframing the thought. This shows how powerful our thoughts can be in influencing our feelings.

I'm curious, what was it like for you to go through this process of challenging your negative thought about your writing?

Patient: It was empowering. It made me realize that just because I have a thought doesn't mean it's true. And even if there's some truth to it, like the fact that my pain does make writing more challenging, it doesn't mean I have to give up on my dreams.

Therapist: Exactly! Challenging our negative thoughts and finding more balanced alternatives can be incredibly empowering. It helps us see things from a different perspective and opens up new possibilities.

Now, I'd like to introduce a new technique called the downward arrow technique. This technique helps us uncover the deeper beliefs that underlie our automatic thoughts. It involves asking ourselves questions like "If that were true, what would that mean to me?" or "What's the worst part about that?" We keep asking these questions until we reach the core belief that's driving our thoughts and feelings.

For example, let's take the automatic thought you mentioned earlier: "I'll never be a successful writer because of my chronic pain." If we apply the downward arrow technique, we might ask, "If that were true, what would that mean to you?" What do you think your answer might be?

Patient: I guess if that were true, it would mean that my pain is not only causing me physical discomfort but also robbing me of my dreams and ambitions. It would mean that I'm powerless against my pain, and that no matter how hard I try, I'll never be able to achieve my goals.

Therapist: That's a great insight, Jamie. We can see how the thought "I'll never be a successful writer because of my chronic pain" might be connected to deeper beliefs about being powerless and unable to achieve your goals. These types of beliefs are what we call intermediate beliefs, and they often stem from even deeper core beliefs about ourselves, others, and the world.

By using the downward arrow technique, we can start to uncover these intermediate and core beliefs and begin to challenge them, just like we did with your automatic thoughts. Would you be willing to try this technique with another thought you've been struggling with?

Patient: Yes, I'm willing to try. There's another thought that's been bothering me a lot lately: "I'm a burden to my loved ones because of my depression and chronic pain."

Therapist: Okay, let's apply the downward arrow technique to this thought. If it were true that you're a burden to your loved ones because of your depression and chronic pain, what would that mean to you?
